resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Anne of Austria (1601-1666), Infanta of Spain and Queen of France (1615-1643), mother of Louis XIV and Philippe of Orléans. No longer alive when the painting was made. As the matriarch of the family, she is portrayed as Cybele, mother goddess of fertility and sits at the exact centre of the painting. She is holding a globe symbolising her political power as Queen regent (1643-1651).
resource.chars: Anne of Austria (1601-1666), Infanta of Spain and Queen of France (1615-1643), mother of Louis XIV and Philippe of Orléans. No longer alive when the painting was made. As the matriarch of the family, she is portrayed as Cybele, mother goddess of fertility and sits at the exact centre of the painting. She is holding a globe symbolising her political power as Queen regent (1643-1651).

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Maria Theresa of Spain (1638-1683), Queen of France (1660-1683) and wife of Louis XIV. She is portrayed as Juno, queen of the gods.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Anne Marie Louise of Orléans, Duchess of Montpensier, known as "La Grande Mademoiselle" (1627-1693), cousin of Louis XIV and heiress of a massive fortune which she decided to manage independently. She is portrayed as Diane, goddess of the moon and the hunt.
resource.chars: Anne Marie Louise of Orléans, Duchess of Montpensier, known as "La Grande Mademoiselle" (1627-1693), cousin of Louis XIV and heiress of a massive fortune which she decided to manage independently. She is portrayed as Diane, goddess of the moon and the hunt.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Henrietta Maria of France (1609-1669), aunt of Louis XIV, Queen consort of England, Scotland and Ireland (1625-1649). She is here portrayed as Amphitrite, goddess of the sea, consort of Poseidon, holding a trident and coral. She was no longer alive when the portrait was made.
resource.chars: Henrietta Maria of France (1609-1669), aunt of Louis XIV, Queen consort of England, Scotland and Ireland (1625-1649). She is here portrayed as Amphitrite, goddess of the sea, consort of Poseidon, holding a trident and coral. She was no longer alive when the portrait was made.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Marie Louise d'Orléans (1669-1689), future Queen of Spain, daughter of Philippe, Duke of Orléans and Princess Henrietta of England. She is portrayed as Iris, goddess of the rainbow with her distinctive butterfly wings.
resource.chars: Marie Louise d'Orléans (1669-1689), future Queen of Spain, daughter of Philippe, Duke of Orléans and Princess Henrietta of England. She is portrayed as Iris, goddess of the rainbow with her distinctive butterfly wings.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Henrietta Anne of England (1644-1670), first wife of Philippe of Orléans (1661), daughter of King Charles I of England and Queen Henrietta Maria and mother of Marie Louise. She is here portrayed as Flora, goddess of spring.
resource.chars: Henrietta Anne of England (1644-1670), first wife of Philippe of Orléans (1661), daughter of King Charles I of England and Queen Henrietta Maria and mother of Marie Louise. She is here portrayed as Flora, goddess of spring.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Louis, Dauphin of France (1661-1711), eldest son and heir apparent of Louis XIV and Maria Theresa of Spain, future grandfather of King Louis XV. He is portrayed here as Hymen, god of marriage and son of Apollo, holding a bridal torch and wearing a crown of laurels (like his father).
resource.chars: Louis, Dauphin of France (1661-1711), eldest son and heir apparent of Louis XIV and Maria Theresa of Spain, future grandfather of King Louis XV. He is portrayed here as Hymen, god of marriage and son of Apollo, holding a bridal torch and wearing a crown of laurels (like his father).

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Louis XIV (1638-1715), King of France (1643-1715), known as the "Sun King", is portrayed here as Apollo, god of light, music and arts, knowledge and truth. He is wearing a luxurious golden garment and holding a sceptre in the form of the sun.
resource.chars: Louis XIV (1638-1715), King of France (1643-1715), known as the "Sun King", is portrayed here as Apollo, god of light, music and arts, knowledge and truth. He is wearing a luxurious golden garment and holding a sceptre in the form of the sun.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Two children of Philippe of Orléans and Henrietta Anne of England portrayed as winged Amores playing with a lyre. Presumably Philippe Charles of Orléans, Duke of Valois (1664-1666) and Anne Marie of Orléans (1669-1728) future Queen of Sardinia.
resource.chars: Two children of Philippe of Orléans and Henrietta Anne of England portrayed as winged Amores playing with a lyre. Presumably Philippe Charles of Orléans, Duke of Valois (1664-1666) and Anne Marie of Orléans (1669-1728) future Queen of Sardinia.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: The three daughters of Gaston of Orléans and Marguerite of Lorraine, cousins of Louis XIV : Marguerite Louise of Orléans (1645-1721), Elisabeth Marguerite of Orléans (1646-1696) and Françoise Madeleine of Orléans (1648-1664), the latter of whom had died at the time of the painting. They are portrayed here as the Three Graces.
resource.chars: The three daughters of Gaston of Orléans and Marguerite of Lorraine, cousins of Louis XIV : Marguerite Louise of Orléans (1645-1721), Elisabeth Marguerite of Orléans (1646-1696) and Françoise Madeleine of Orléans (1648-1664), the latter of whom had died at the time of the painting. They are portrayed here as the Three Graces.
